speaker: Episode 64 - The Stolen Century - Chapter Five
Griffin
lines: Previously, on the Adventure Zone

speaker: Travis
lines: Uh, my background is that of a carpenter. Um, who has become a folk hero.

speaker: Griffin
lines: You built a tight chair once.

speaker: Travis
lines: Yeah.

speaker: Griffin
lines: You built a chair once and the whole village came around.

speaker: Travis
lines: I built an army out of wood.

speaker: Griffin
lines: Uh huh.

speaker: Griffin
lines: You are seeing a memory and you know that you are seeing it from the perspective of the Voidfish. You’re inside a cave, it feels like home. And you know that because there’s other Voidfish here too.

speaker: Barry
lines: I don’t wanna be- I don’t wanna embarrass myself in front of, and like, for example, just like, for example like, Lup.

speaker: Taako
lines: We’ve lost a lot. There’s a lot more we might lose but the one thing we do have, is the thing that people in love rarely ever have enough of. And it’s time.

speaker: Griffin
lines: So, Chancellor Marlow takes you to the Legato Conservatory. And when the light clears, the sheet music’s gone. And so is the song. There’s another flash from the cave, and we see everyone in all the kingdoms and conservatories in this whole world, um, even the beings living in the other planes of reality, they all hear this song too, now.

speaker: Marlow
lines: Well, that’s the Light of Creation. Any questions?

speaker: Announcer
lines: We’re almost caught up. Do you understand yet? It’s imperative you pay attention. This isn’t just some story. It’s the Adventure Zone!

speaker: Griffin
lines: So it’s immediately after that musical, um, presentation here at the stage in front of the cave. And, um, the seven of you have talked a little bit with Chancellor Marlow about what you just saw, about this phenomenon that Chancellor Marlow [crosstalk] claimed to be the—

speaker: Travis
lines: [crosstalk] Now, h— hold on, Griffin. Hold— hold on. Don’t jump ahead.

speaker: Griffin
lines: Okay.

speaker: Travis
lines: We’re at a reception, right, recital?

speaker: Griffin
lines: Yeah.

speaker: Travis
lines: We’re kinda like, are there apps? Is it like the— are the beer and the wine free?

speaker: Griffin
lines: So there are—

speaker: Clint
lines: Tapas? I love tapas.

speaker: Griffin
lines: There’s tapas. There’s a lot of finger sandwiches, and, a like, ah, uh, there’s probably lemonade. Nobody’s really getting into it though because you get the impression that this type of ceremony happens a lot. And, like, if folks snacked, like if folks yummied down on these sandwiches and lemonade like every time they came here, probably be bad for the, probably be bad for the, you know, digestion. But there’s plenty [crosstalk] if you wanna—

speaker: Clint
lines: [crosstalk] Well that doesn’t keep us from doin’ it though, right?

speaker: Griffin
lines: Yeah you snack— you snack down.

speaker: Clint
lines: [makes eating sounds]

speaker: Travis
lines: I take a whole tray of finger sandwiches and I’m— I’m listening intently, don’t— I don’t need my teeth to listen, you know what I mean?

speaker: Griffin
lines: Sure. Uh, so Chancellor Marlow explains about this phenomenon that you heard her call ‘The Light of Creation’ earlier. Um, and so the first thing you learn about this cave is that nobody can go into it. It’s not just like a hard and fast rule for all of the conservatories— all of which are sort of built around this mountain, sort of with their own caves leading into it— so it’s not just the law of the land, like, when you try to walk in, there’s a flash of light and suddenly you are walking out, just— just the way that you came. There are rumors though, of a Forte Conservatory student who made their way into the school— uh, the the cave’s entrance— uh, their school’s entrance, into the mountain, after having their song selected by the light.

speaker: So after conversing with Marlow and with each other, and sort of relating to her the dire importance of your mission, she offers a suggestion. You spend this year training at the Legato Conservatory, and you submit a work to the mountain. Um. To— to what she and everyone else calls ‘The Light of Creation’. And if it’s accepted, you might be able to gain access inside. So that is the set up for this cycle, um, and… what do you work on this year? What craft do you work on, uh, what work do you submit to, to, ah the cave?
Travis
lines: Well, okay so this is my question. Does it have to be music?

speaker: Griffin
lines: No, it doesn’t have to be music. Marlow explains like these—the conservatory has specialties in like all of these different, um, forms, and all of these different, um… uh, like artistic mediums. There are sculptors, and painters, and dancers, and… Um. there are, you know… um, uh, wood carvers and there are singers. And [crosstalk] writers—

speaker: Travis
lines: [crosstalk] W— wood carvers?

speaker: Griffin
lines: And yeah, like, so you know sculptors of all kinds of different mediums.

speaker: Travis
lines: So would, like, carving wood with like knives and… like blades; weapons. Yeah?

speaker: Griffin
lines: [Smiling] Yeah, you— well I mean they have special knives and they don’t use like a big— they don’t use like a big scimitar or whatever. But I guess there are sharp instruments used.

speaker: Travis
lines: That immediately interests Magnus.

speaker: Griffin
lines: [Smiling] Because it’s a thing you can do with weapons?

speaker: Travis
lines: Yup.

speaker: Griffin
lines: Mkay.

speaker: Travis
lines: At fir— At first!

speaker: Griffin
lines: Yeah, sure.

speaker: Travis
lines: He has not learned the artistry of carving, Griffin. So it’s just seems violent to him, right? And so that’s interesting—

speaker: Griffin
lines: Uh, okay—

speaker: Travis
lines: [Crosstalk] You know?

speaker: Griffin
lines: W— we’ll do yours first then while Taako and Merle—

speaker: Travis
lines: It was either gonna be that or drumming. [Laughs]

speaker: Griffin
lines: [Laughs] That would also be very good. We’ll do yours first while Taako and Merle sorta think of their, um, their mediums. So yeah, I guess you get matched up with a wood carver who is also like a, just a very gruff and… Um. He has a very violent approach to art. And just gives you like a big log every day to just— and I think when you start out, the professor whose name is Professor Kristoph— Kristoph Kovaks on Twitter, thank you Kristoph— uh, it— it’s just like,

speaker: Professor Kristoph
lines: Yes, Magnus, attack the wood. Show it your fury until beauty comes out of that— that big, sweet round log.

speaker: Travis
lines: And I wanna be straight up, it’s terrible at first.

speaker: Griffin
lines: Oh, no, yeah! I mean, how do you get to Carnegie Hall?

speaker: Travis
lines: I don’t know.

speaker: Clint
lines: Take a left? At… 4th Street...

speaker: Griffin
lines: Um, Magnus make a— since, uh, since the way you’ve set this up it sounds like your art on this wood is sort of an a— it starts off with just sort of attacking, so I guess make a body roll, um, plus body. Body roll sounds like a sick dance move.

speaker: Travis
lines: Well, Griffin, I’ll be honest with you, it wasn’t great. And here’s why, here’s my justification I think that attacking the wood does not prove to actually be—

speaker: Griffin
lines: [Crosstalk] Oh, I see.

speaker: Travis
lines: —Magnus’s forte, so I wanted him— I’m glad he failed at it.

speaker: Griffin
lines: Okay.

speaker: Travis
lines: Because I would actually rather transition to working with a teacher who’s like “No no no no no. Clearly attacking the wood is not your strength. It is finding within the wood the thing that it wants to be.”

speaker: Griffin
lines: Okay, then you [laughing] you have a different professor, I have to get another name from Twitter. Um…

speaker: Travis
lines: Mm-hm?

speaker: Griffin
lines: Professor Bauer— Johnathan Bauer, thank you, on Twitter— uh, who’s like

speaker: Professor Bauer
lines: You know what you need to try, you know what you need to try Magnus? Magnus, you know what it’s time to try? Lil’ bit of tenderness.

speaker: Travis
lines: Oh, okay! Well, I got an 11! Is that tender enough?

speaker: Griffin
lines: That’s extremely tender, what’s the first thing you carve that you, like, really like?

speaker: Travis
lines: It’s a duck, baby.

speaker: Justin
lines: Natch.

speaker: Griffin
lines: [Laughs] A big duck, a handheld duck, what’s the…?

speaker: Travis
lines: Listen, it’s a slightly clumsy duck-sized duck. Um, you know a little— listen, little knobbly. Um, and there’s like, you know a couple spots where you can see like, a drop of blood that’s soaked into the wood, you know, where like I nicked myself doing it. But within it, it’s like somebody took a lot of time and care to do this thing that they were not inherently good at.

speaker: Griffin
lines: Mm-hm.

speaker: Travis
lines: And so, in and of itself, its imperfection is what makes it beautiful.

speaker: Griffin
lines: You get an ‘A’ on your duck. Very tender. And Professor Bauer asks if this is what you want to submit to the cave, after your year of study.

speaker: Travis
lines: I will tell you right now, Magnus has never been prouder of anything than he is of this duck.

speaker: Griffin
lines: Okay, take +2 experience for learning this sort of essential tradecraft to the Magnus backstory. Uh, Taako and Merle? Do either of you have a medium that you want to sort of develop some mastery in during the year?

speaker: Clint
lines: Um…

speaker: Merle
lines: I wanna become proficient, in the dance.

speaker: Griffin
lines: What style of dance? There’s so much dance.

speaker: Merle
lines: Interpretive. Interpretive jazz dancing. Where you tell the story with both body and hands.

speaker: Griffin
lines: There’s two— there’s a professor for jazz dancing and there’s a professor for interpretive dancing, and—

speaker: Travis
lines: They are two completely different art forms.

speaker: Griffin
lines: It’s two completely different art forms and they don’t really, um... they don’t really get along. And so after like a few sessions of— like both of them trying to train you, I think they just kind of leave you to yourself. So after you’ve learned some of the basic steps of both crafts, I think it’s just up to you to sort of look within and find the interpretive jazz inside yourself, and sort of bring that out into the world. Um—

speaker: Clint
lines: The jazz in Merle.

speaker: Griffin
lines: How do you, mmm… I think this would also be a body roll too, because it’s like dance, like it’s very physical.

speaker: Travis
lines: You do do body rolls in dance, Griffin, that’s likely.

speaker: Griffin
lines: You do do a body roll.

speaker: Clint
lines: All right, body roll. [Rolls dice] 10!

speaker: Griffin
lines: Holy shit! Your body’s not like your thing. That’s very good.

speaker: Clint
lines: A— and— yeah!

speaker: Griffin
lines: I think after a while you are sort of brought on as an adjunct professor to this new type of dance.

speaker: Travis
lines: [Laughs loudly]

speaker: Clint
lines: Oh!

speaker: Griffin
lines: At Legato, at the Legato Conservatory. And I think—

speaker: Clint
lines: [Crosstalk] Yea-ha-ha!

speaker: Griffin
lines: I think those two professors, at the end of the— the movie of Merle Presents Save the Last Dance, they get together and sort of realize the error of their ways. And all of a sudden, like, people from the other conservatories start like flocking to, to this one. They start transferring to this school just to, just to learn this interpretive jazz dance that’s just sweeping the nation, that people are getting so excited about.

speaker: Can you describe the dance and I think you just would like submit a step chart; what does the dance look like that you submit to the cave?
Clint
lines: Um, the first— the first thing that happens is you have your feet completely right next to each other, and then you shift your feet so they’re like at a 90 degree angle. Uh—

speaker: Griffin
lines: That would—

speaker: Clint
lines: And then you do a lot of scissor steps.

speaker: Griffin
lines: Okay.

speaker: Clint
lines: Uh, and now here’s the thing, you do scissor steps with your feet front, back, front, back, front, back, but with your arms, you go scissors, in, uh, the air up and down, up and down, up and down.

speaker: Griffin
lines: Okay.

speaker: Travis
lines: What about the hands, man! What do you do with the hands?!

speaker: Clint
lines: Well the hands are alternating, uh, and this is where the interpretive comes in. You, we are using the hands as almost like signals. Uh, like you— creatively you’re making shapes—

speaker: Griffin
lines: [Crosstalk] Okay.

speaker: Clint
lines: Like if you were making shadows without light.

speaker: Griffin
lines: So aphorisms- what are you interpreting, what sort of motif or idea or emotion? I’m watching you do this awesome scissor dance. What do I feel?

speaker: Clint
lines: Uh, pity?

speaker: Travis
lines: Well.

speaker: Clint
lines: Um… No I, it’s very moving, and— because you can see what I’m trying to get at is… is man’s injustices—

speaker: Griffin
lines: [Crosstalk] Woah.

speaker: Clint
lines: Against other mans.

speaker: Griffin
lines: [Laughing slightly] Okay.

speaker: Clint
lines: And that’s— this is— because you can see this— this poor figure, trying to... well, to touch God.

speaker: Justin
lines: Mmm.

speaker: Griffin
lines: Oh you— so it’s the— is perhaps the name of the dance God Touch?

speaker: Clint
lines: Uh, it’s actually called A Pan-demonium. Pandemonium.

speaker: Griffin
lines: Fuck that’s good.

speaker: Clint
lines: Yeah.

speaker: Griffin
lines: Take two— take two experience, just for the name.

speaker: Clint
lines: Oh, cool.

speaker: Griffin
lines: Uh, Taako, what are you workin’ on?

speaker: Justin
lines: Mmm. My art is… the subtle art of aphorisms.

speaker: Griffin
lines: I dunno what that means.

speaker: Justin
lines: Um. It means—

speaker: Griffin
lines: Is that where you touch the bumps on people’s heads to like read the future?

speaker: Justin
lines: No, like little sayings— that’s phrenology I think— little sayings that contain a lotta truth and sound very wise.

speaker: Griffin
lines: [Laughs]

speaker: Justin
lines: And that’s my art form. But what Taako’s doing is, um, really just recycling ones that exist in his reality and probably not this one and crediting them to himself.

speaker: Griffin
lines: [Laughs]

speaker: Justin
lines: ‘Cause he figured that would be an easy thing to do for a year.

speaker: Griffin
lines: This is Hurley writing Empire Strikes Back on Lost, like.

speaker: Justin
lines: Exactly, right, exactly.

speaker: Griffin
lines: You have- you have a Poor Richard’s Almanack, and you’re like, “Mm don’t mind if I do, thank you Ben”.

speaker: Justin
lines: Yeah, so that’s his- his jam. He just like, goes in Day 1, and is like,

speaker: Taako
lines: “How many cares one loses when one decides not to be something, but to be someone.”

speaker: Justin
lines: Which he knows is a quote by Coco Chanel, but he just like spits it—

speaker: Griffin
lines: [Crosstalk] Yeah.

speaker: Justin
lines: No hesitation. [crosstalk] And everyone’s like—

speaker: Clint
lines: [crosstalk] Naw, yeah.

speaker: Griffin
lines: [crosstalk] Well, fantasy Koko Chanel. If such a being could- [crosstalk] could ever truly—

speaker: Justin
lines: [crosstalk] Fantasy Koko Chanel.

speaker: Clint
lines: [crosstalk] And it’s spelled K-O-K-O.

speaker: Griffin
lines: Okay? I think there’s probably like a philosophy class in the school that you sort of come into and just start dropping all these fuckin’ bombs. And the philosophy professor’s just really annoyed by it? I think at first. Until they realize like,

speaker: Philosophy Professor
lines: Wow, Taako, this guy might be onto some shit actually.

speaker: Griffin
lines: Can you break me off another piece ‘cause I think you probably have a website open.

speaker: Justin
lines: I don’t, I just have these in my head.

speaker: Griffin
lines: You have this Coco Cha— you have this dope ass Coco Chanel quote?

speaker: Justin
lines: It’s a dope quote, I have a lot of quotes about being yourself that I just memorized to help me-, keep me grounded.

speaker: Travis
lines: They’re all Coco Chanel [Laughs].

speaker: Justin
lines: Here’s another Coco Chanel. [Laughs] Uh,

speaker: Taako
lines: [in Justin’s voice] “Be who you are and say what you feel because those who mind don’t matter and those who matter don’t mind.”

speaker: Justin
lines: That’s Dr. Seuss right there.

speaker: Griffin
lines: [deep] Fuck.

speaker: Justin
lines: Now it’s— now it’s Taako, over here. In this joint, that’s a Taako thing.

speaker: Clint
lines: Wow.

speaker: Griffin
lines: Roll a—

speaker: Clint
lines: How ‘bout um, “Here I sit all broken-hearted—”

speaker: Justin
lines: Don’t you dare.

speaker: Travis
lines: Nope.

speaker: Clint
lines: Okay.

speaker: Griffin
lines: Don’t you dare do this. Um, roll plus mind, I think.

speaker: Justin
lines: Okay. That is… 11.

speaker: Griffin
lines: Wow, all good rolls! Everybody’s kinda killin’ it at the Conservatory.

speaker: Justin
lines: I feel like I should be running this class.

speaker: Griffin
lines: Um, yeah I think you—

speaker: Justin
lines: ‘Cause he’s just saying things other people say, and I’m coming up with my own dope shit.

speaker: Griffin
lines: Well, kind of. I think that [Clint laughs] I think you lead sort of an Order-of-the-Phoenix-style like alt-philosophy class that’s all about just like, being yourself and connecting with who you really are. And that definitely attracts a lot of the students here ‘cause this conservatory and all the conservatories are very competitive, and so there’s people who come to see you and they’re like,

speaker: Student
lines: You know what maybe I don’t wanna do my art the way everybody else does it. Maybe I wanna be myself. Maybe I- maybe I wanna explore the me that Taako says I can be.

speaker: Griffin
lines: And--

speaker: Justin
lines: Yeah, don’t look for society to give you permission to be yourself.

speaker: Clint
lines: Mm.

speaker: Justin
lines: Think about that.

speaker: Griffin
lines: Was that someone else or did you- was that off the dome?

speaker: Justin
lines: Mm, hmm? Yeah, it’s Steve Maraboli. Uh- it doesn’t matter.

speaker: Griffin
lines: So--

speaker: Taako
lines: “Where’s your will to be weird?”

speaker: Justin
lines: Jim Morrison. But now Taako.

speaker: Griffin
lines: [Laughs] Um, do you write these down in a book to submit to the- the mountain?

speaker: Justin
lines: Yeah.

speaker: Griffin
lines: Okay.

speaker: Clint
lines: Aw, I think somebody writes ‘em down for him.

speaker: Griffin
lines: What’s--

speaker: Justin
lines: I probably don’t- yeah that- thank you Dad. Of course, I don’t do the scribing myself.

speaker: Griffin
lines: Is the book--

speaker: Justin
lines: It opens with “Some people say you’re going the wrong way, when it’s simply a way of your own.” Now that used to be Angelina Jolie, but uh, now it’s Taako.

speaker: Griffin
lines: [Claps and laughs] That’s my favorite Taako quote. What’s the book called?

speaker: Justin
lines: Uh, Taako’s- Taako T-- [Laughs]

speaker: Griffin
lines: [Laughs]

speaker: Taako
lines: Taako Time! A Book of Inspirational Aphorisms for the  Independent Soul.

speaker: Griffin
lines: Aw, shit that’s good. Okay. Take +2 experience, everybody gets +2 experience points.

speaker: Travis
lines: Hey Griffin, I would like to retroactively add something--

speaker: Griffin
lines: Okay yes.

speaker: Travis
lines: -- just to prove to people that I haven’t forgotten about it.

speaker: Griffin
lines: Okay.

speaker: Travis
lines: Uh, I carved that duck with my grandfather’s knife that I claimed to have in the first episode of this very podcast!

speaker: Griffin
lines: Uh, okay yeah, sure. You still have that beau- that wonderful knife that you use for all your carvin’. Um, let’s get to- it’s close to the end of the year, you have about, uh, you have a couple weeks left before you know the Hunger is going to arrive and so you all are scheduled for a submission-- all seven of you-- uh and, the ceremony is more or less identical to the one you went to at the beginning of the year.

speaker: And you probably went to a few of these, as you sorta got to know the other students are here at the Conservatory and go to like support them as they submit their works. And this is like, this is a really, um... it’s a terrifying thing to do. Uh, because more often than not, the mountain does not sort of rebroadcast whatever it is that you submit to it. So every time that you work your ass off on this thing that you are proud of and submit it to the mountain, um, there is no guarantee that it’s going to be accepted, and therefore it’s going to be sort of eliminated, completely.

Um, eliminated even from your own mind, you won’t remember what this thing is that you made. Um… so you go the ceremony and there’s the same sandwiches and lemonade, and the seven of you take turns going up to stage, presenting your work… which for the three of you must be a pretty fun sight. And Magnus, what’s yours look like? ‘Cause you made a duck and you’re--
Travis
lines: Yeah, here’s- I’ll tell ya, Griffin, here’s the thing, I’ve been sittin’ here thinking about it and I think that, in the moment when he finished the duck, I think Magnus was insanely proud of it. ‘Cause it’s something like he worked at, and took his time at. That he didn’t normally do. But I think that seeing people present these masterpieces, these beautiful songs, or artworks that they’ve created, I think that he actually gets a little embarrassed?

speaker: Griffin
lines: Mm.

speaker: Travis
lines: About it, because like he’s looking at this like, knobbly, you know stained duck. And I actually think he’s- he’s a little embarrassed that he was so proud of it.

speaker: Griffin
lines: Oh, no. Um, Professor Bauer comes, ‘cause your professor always goes up there with you when you submit a work. And he puts his hand on your shoulder and he’s like

speaker: Professor Bauer
lines: That’s a real good duck. Show ‘em the duck, it’s a good duck, I think they’ll like it.

speaker: Travis
lines: Actually making me feel a li’l bad for Magnus, but he presents it and whispers,

speaker: Magnus
lines: It’s not perfect, but it’s the best I can do.

speaker: Griffin
lines: I think there’s a uncomfortable smattering of applause, just from people not really knowing how to respond to somebody being quite this... self-effacing? Um, there’s a couple people though who are like,

speaker: Person 1
lines: ‘Ey, great duck!

speaker: Person 2
lines: ‘Ey! ‘Ey, great lil’ mallard, buddy! Keep your chin up.

speaker: Griffin
lines: And Merle I guess your presentation is--

speaker: Clint
lines: I, uh- uh- uh- uh! Professor Merle.

speaker: Griffin
lines: Professor Merle, what is your presentation to the audience?

speaker: Clint
lines: I’m going to actually recreate my dance.

speaker: Griffin
lines: Okay.

speaker: Clint
lines: Uh, and I--

speaker: Griffin
lines: Is there music to the dance?

speaker: Clint
lines: I have actually the music in me. Um, but it’s kind of a, [rhythmically] oontz, oontz, oontz, oontz, oontz, oontz, oontz, okay I’m done.

speaker: Griffin
lines: Mm my favorite- my favorite jazz rhythm.

speaker: Clint
lines: Yeah, oontz oontz. And I have added one little wrinkle, I’ve got my arms akimbo. And my fingers are dangling down below, and with that, I am acting like tentacles.

speaker: Griffin
lines: Okay.

speaker: Clint
lines: Uh, and there’s a lot of head gyrations, there’s a lot of head rolls--

speaker: Griffin
lines: Yeah.

speaker: Clint
lines: -- uh, and just because I am Professor Merle, a couple of pelvic thrusts.

speaker: Justin
lines: Mmm!

speaker: Griffin
lines: I don’t see why that has to do with, being a teacher.

speaker: Clint
lines: Well, it’s the sensuality because this is--

speaker: Griffin
lines: [Laughs]

speaker: Clint
lines: -- a very sensual dance. The interpretive jazz dancing is very sensual, very physic- it’s like belly dancing.

speaker: Griffin
lines: Yeah, the way you’ve described it, it sounds [crosstalk] very sensual.

speaker: Clint
lines: [crosstalk] And I just am in- at one point, I am so caught up in the dance, I completely lose myself, and I finish up whirling like a Dervish and just going mad, becoming one with the universe, and then collapse in a sweaty, dwarfy heap.

speaker: Griffin
lines: Um, the audience applauds hornily.

speaker: Griffin
lines: Um, Davenport gets up on the stage, and sings a beautiful, tenor opera solo, that goes on for like, eighteen minutes. But you are enraptured the entire time. He’s got a lovely-

speaker: Clint
lines: [Crossover sings Ave Maria]

speaker: Griffin
lines: -beautiful lil’ voice that sort of echoes down the valley, that these presentations take place in. Um, and… Lucretia gets up and presents a painting that she made. She does a painting of this, like famous city market square, like this, public space? That was a really sort of beautiful fixture of the town that the IPRE headquarters was in, in your home. And it’s been 50 years but like, you all remember this little space, and it’s just sort of like a still life scene of all these people congregating in this public square and it’s a- she was a very talented painter before this year and she’s only gotten better. Taako, what is your- what is your presentation of your aphorism book look like?

speaker: Justin
lines: I walk up to a pedestal, and I drop my book on the pedestal, and say,

speaker: Taako
lines: You’re all very welcome.

speaker: Justin
lines: And then I walk off the stage.

speaker: Clint
lines: Yeah.

speaker: Griffin
lines: Uh, all of the students who’ve like attended your outdoor, uh, sermons I guess? Are like, very enthused. Like,

speaker: Student
lines: Yeah, that’s how he does it. That’s how he does it!

speaker: Taako
lines: Yeah I’ll leave- I’ll leave you with these two thoughts, that I just- I’m coming up with two for you right now, hold on.

speaker: Clint
lines: [Laughs]

speaker: Taako
lines: [Inhales] “Nothing makes one feel so strong as a call for help.”

speaker: Clint
lines: Oh.

speaker: Justin
lines: Do they like that one?

speaker: Clint
lines: That’s good. [Quieter] That’s good.

speaker: Griffin
lines: Um--

speaker: Justin
lines: And that’s one of the Pope’s, I don’t remember which one.

speaker: Clint

speaker: Griffin
lines: [Laughs] Uh, the last two— the last two people to present their work to the audience and to the mountain, is Barry and Lup. Um, and you haven’t like seen them much this cycle? They’ve been spending like a lot of, uh, time together. Specifically working on this work that they are going to present to everybody. And it’s not uncommon for them to like, go off like this. Like they are… at this point like, very close collaborators on a lot of the things that they do.

speaker: Most of the time in like studying different parts of the worlds that you’re in. But this time they got together to… to work on this very very specific craft. And as they approach the stage and sit down, Taako, you can’t remember the last time you saw Lup nervous, but she is. Barry’s always nervous and he’s in rare form here, but Lup also seems kind of anxious, about this performance. And she walks up, and she picks up a violin, and Barry sits down at a big grand piano, and they play a duet. And in watching them play this composition, you realize, really for the first time, just how profoundly Barry and Lup’s relationship has changed.

Time is different for the seven of you, than it has been for anyone else who ever lived. During your one-hundred year journey, you don’t age thanks to whatever forces keep putting you back together at the beginning of each year. Your minds stay sharp. You learn skills and languages and new proficiencies. You become remarkably capable adventurers during your voyage on the Starblaster. But it’s not just your minds that develop, across this ageless century, something less quantifiable develops too.
[Salut D’Amour by Edward Elgar starts playing]

Our capacity for love increases with each person we cross paths with throughout our lives, and with each moment we spend with those people. But, too often we neglect that part of ourselves in favor of others. And by the time we realize just how important it is, we find ourselves with fewer folks around to practice with. But the seven of you have something that nobody else ever had
lines: time. All the time in the world. Time enough to grow indescribably close. Time enough to learn how to care for each other, how to allow yourselves to be cared for. And in the case of Barry and Lup, time enough to fall deeply and truly in love.

speaker: Barry felt it first. During a particularly challenging year, Lup caught him crying. And she softly and sincerely consoled him, and just for a moment, the professional wall between them came down. And something shone through. Lup wasn’t far behind; her moment of realization was a bit more innocuous. During that cycle with the robots, Barry helped repair the small frame of a vessel housing a particularly rambunctious spirit, and it kept shocking him, and laughing. And Lup laughed too, and she knew.

This new love, it wasn’t their focus during the journey. Barry worked tirelessly to understand each world you traveled to, to understand the Hunger and figure out a way to defeat it. Lup grew furiously in arcane power, studying the mystical secrets of the planes, hoping to master whatever spell would break your team out of their desperate retreat. But there were moments between those studies, meals shared in secret, just the two of them under the guise of their work, sightseeing trips for two across these doomed worlds. And that love grew, and it grew, until it reached the point that all great loves grow toward
lines: the point of… inevitability.

speaker: Looking back, this performance is where that love that Barry and Lup cultivated quietly and cautiously over the last half century truly bloomed. There was romance in every measure, and longing in every note. And after the performance, they, they take each other’s hands high in the air, and they swoop down for this over-the-top bow, just laughing at the, the drama of it all. And the audience cheers. And Barry and Lup laugh, and they don’t let each other’s hands go. And then they stop laughing, and they don’t let each other’s hands go. And they keep not letting go. And Lup says,
Lup
lines: Barry, do you wanna go talk somewhere for a while?

speaker: Griffin
lines: And Barry says,

speaker: Barry
lines: [Wholeheartedly] Yeah.

speaker: Griffin
lines: And Lup goes and puts their sheet music up on the pedestal, and there’s a flash of light from the cave. And the beautiful duet they just played is gone from your minds, and seconds later there’s a second flash, and the song returns, and there’s a roar of applause from the audience. And Barry and Lup’s professor is searching for them in the crowd, just hoping to congratulate them. But they’re already gone,

speaker: [Salut D’Amour by Edward Elgar performed by Emanuel Salvador starts playing]
Running back up the valley to the Conservatory, hand in hand.

speaker: Griffin
lines: And she shows this fish some of the drawings in her, uh, in her book. In her books, I guess. And the Voidfish, warms up, and kind of brushes up against her, and she kind of laughs. And sure enough this baby fish leads you deeper and back into the cave. {5532}

speaker: And the first time Lucretia comes with you, um, those other fish, the bigger ones kind of come over to her, um… one of them- there’s like a pretty big pond in the center of this chamber, that these, uh, stalactites are just constantly dripping down into-- One of these fish, just like splashes out of the pond, and like splashes Lucretia, in like a huge, like sit-too-close-at-Seaworld wave. And she like turns her- she turns quick and tries to get her books away, but gets like doused by this water. And she’s like kind of horrified. She’s like,
Lucretia
lines: Oh, god. Oh, god. It’s doesn’t smell very good, Magnus. It got in my mouth. This is awful. Why do you keep coming--

speaker: Magnus
lines: That was a mistake. That was a mistake. Duh, you gotta keep your mouth closed in situations like- once you get splashed trust me, what do you want, pink eye? You gotta close your eyes, cover your mouth, c’mon. It’s day one stuff.

speaker: Griffin
lines: So you hang out with Lucretia and the Voidfish. How many over the next like few days, how many ducks do you bring in. {5640}

speaker: Travis
lines: Aw man, I think I can max do three ducks a day--

speaker: Griffin
lines: Okay.

speaker: Travis
lines: --but don’t get me wrong, they’re getting better. You know what I mean? There’s definite duck improvement.

speaker: Griffin
lines: Lucretia like spends her time in this cavern with you. You spend it like sort of hanging out and playing ducks, with the baby fish, while Lucretia like, illustrates some of these creatures, tries to like understand their anatomy. Um, also she--

speaker: Travis
lines: I also- I don’t wanna miss an opportunity, Ditto, I’d also love to like, petition the fish, the jellyfish and see if they know anything about the Light of Creation. I mean as long as we’re looking for help, they’ve collected all this information and they know all of these things- I would love to try to convey to them what I’m looking for? {5626}

speaker: Griffin
lines: Yeah, I mean this conversation is just gonna be always sort of, by nature of the thing, like, one-sided? I don’t think that they know how to like, tell you whether or not they know what you’re talking about.

speaker: Travis
lines: Gotcha.

speaker: Griffin
lines: But you spend a lotta time with this creature, this baby fish, the smallest one, the one that always leads you into the cave. And, you feel this like- you feel a bond with it. Um, take +2 bond. Um, for spending time here with Lucretia and spending time with this baby Voidfish. Um, and--

speaker: Travis
lines: Can I just address the elephant in the room, Griffin?

speaker: Griffin
lines: Yeah.

speaker: Travis
lines: I’m not leaving that fish behind. {5807}

speaker: [Creepy music (Wind Dance by Mort Garson) plays]
Griffin
lines: When the Hunger comes to this world, for the first time in a long time, the seven of you are, surprised. It’s early by a couple of days. And, unlike its other appearances where it kind of forms like a storm overhead and then touches down across the world erratically, it’s just, BOOM. It’s just immediately on top of you.

speaker: Um, you’re having breakfast in the Conservatory lounge and then the sky turns black and the grass turns gray, and it’s just there. It’s like it knew where you were. Um, and immediately, Davenport is like
Davenport
lines: Bug out, we’re up in the air in two minutes.

speaker: Griffin
lines: And fuckin’ runs out of the room, uh, towards the Starblaster. Um, and other folks follow suit. Um, Magnus what do you do? {5901}

speaker: Magnus
lines: Lup? Don’t. Leave. Without me.

speaker: Griffin
lines: Uhh--

speaker: Travis
lines: And I go.

speaker: Griffin
lines: Lup says,

speaker: Lup
lines: What are you- why? [Laughs] We need to get- we need to- we gotta bounce. Look up. Look up, bud. It’s, it’s the Big H. It’s time to roll.

speaker: Magnus
lines: Do you remember with the robits? And you stopped us all from doing something terrible?

speaker: Lup
lines: Yeah…

speaker: Magnus
lines: I’m stopping you all. Don’t. Leave. Without me.

speaker: Griffin
lines: Um, she pulls out--

speaker: Travis
lines: And I go, full sprint, full sprint.

speaker: Griffin
lines: Alright, she pulls out a wand, and… Barry pulls out a wand and they turn to all of you and Lup’s like,

speaker: Lup
lines: Um, looks like we need to hold off… the apocalypse, for a few minutes, and buy some time. Y’all down?

speaker: Taako
lines: Hell yeah.

speaker: Merle
lines: Yeah we haven’t fought shit, in like, a month.

speaker: Griffin
lines: Um, so the scene is you, Magnus, rushing, uh into the mouth of the cave, while everyone else is just sort of standing on the Starblaster which is parked out on this lake, sort of adjacent to the valley there. Uh, just sort of firing shots at everything, uh, approaching this ship, and firing shots at things sort of attacking the Conservatory, which, because of your efforts, is partially? Evacuated? Um, Magnus, roll a plus body. {6023}

speaker: Travis
lines: [rolls dice] Hell yeah, that would be an 11.

speaker: Griffin
lines: You make it into the cave so, so fast. And even though the fish isn’t there to greet you at the mouth, you still make it in okay. And you reach the center of the chamber. And all of the big jellyfish that you’ve seen in here, are all sort of submerged under the water of the pond. And the baby jellyfish is sort of floating above it, sort of like singing to them, but they are not, they’re not answering. And it seems kind of panicked. And the ground is starting to sort of shake beneath your feet, and there are rocks sort of peeling off the walls. You see one of the entrances that leads to one of the other conservatories just collapse, like, immediately adjacent to you.

speaker: Travis
lines: Uhh… I pull out a duck. That I have with me.

speaker: Travis
lines: That I was gonna give the fish later.

speaker: Griffin
lines: Okay, it flies over to you, and it sings a song, but you can tell it seems kind of nervous, about all of its like, family members or whatever, not comin’ with. And you hear some- you hear Lucretia’s voice shouting down the mouth of the cave that you just came through, and she’s saying like,

speaker: Lucretia
lines: Magnus, we have to go. Get it or don’t but we’ve gotta go. C’mon.

speaker: Travis
lines: I- can I see the other fishes around?

speaker: Griffin
lines: They’re like under- they’re deep, deep underwater in this pond in the middle of this massive cavern chamber.

speaker: Travis
lines: Uh, I look down into the water and say,

speaker: Magnus
lines: I- I’ll protect it. I promise.

speaker: Travis
lines: And I grab it. And run.

speaker: Griffin
lines: Uh, okay I’ll use that body roll that you used earlier, because like this thing doesn’t understand being grabbed? It doesn’t know what you’re doing. Um, and it kinda fights you a little bit, but you’re just sort of--

speaker: Travis
lines: I start humming. {6211}

speaker: Griffin
lines: O-kay, you’re humming this song that you’ve heard it hum a few times, and it seems to calm it down. And you and Lucretia just sort of race-- she’s like firing off shots too, at these like shadows that are starting to like, full-force sprint at you, as you make your way back to the ship. Um, and she clears a path for you two to, for you three to run back to the Starblaster, and get onboard. And take off. And Davenport like, just throws this thing, like a dart into the sky. Just like, the fastest acceleration that you’ve felt this thing give, this whole time.

speaker: As it launches up into the sky, and as you’re flying up and past the barrier, there’s a moment of tension and anxiety, where you don’t know if this thing’s gonna be there, after you pass through the barrier between realities. You’ve seen, you know, small animals or whatever stay, and you’ve seen people disappear. But as you pass through that barrier, both you and Lucretia are just staring intently at the fish, just desperately hoping, and as your vision clears, you see it. And it’s still floating in front of you. It’s a little confused, obviously, but it’s here, and it’s safe. And it would stay safe for the rest of your journey across existence.

The next year, you and Lucretia find a big glass tank, and she keeps it in her quarters. Her cabin was always bigger than yours. And, you’d go to it, from time to time. To sing it songs, or… give it carvings. Your repertoire expanded but, it still likes your ducks the best. It delighted in your company, Magnus. And it still does.
